articles.headline: Spending a Month’s Salary to See Bad Bunny, Only to Be Turned Away
articles.snippet: The concert was supposed to be one of Mexico’s largest, sold out months before. Instead, one of the world’s biggest stars played to a half empty floor.
articles.abstract: The concert was supposed to be one of Mexico’s largest, sold out months before. Instead, one of the world’s biggest stars played to a half empty floor.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — As Bad Bunny, one of the world’s hottest pop stars, floated on a palm tree crooning to adoring fans for what was supposed to be one of Mexico City’s largest concerts ever, the stadium floor was far from jam-packed.

articles.headline: Global Leaders Mix Sports and Diplomacy at the World Cup
articles.snippet: Dozens of top officials have flown to Qatar to cheer for teams while talking shop. The event has magnified the tiny Gulf nation’s role as a diplomatic broker.
articles.abstract: Dozens of top officials have flown to Qatar to cheer for teams while talking shop. The event has magnified the tiny Gulf nation’s role as a diplomatic broker.
articles.lead_paragraph: They have shown up in the shiny soccer stadiums here in Qatar one after the other, popping up more frequently than yellow cards or penalty goals.

articles.headline: In Subfreezing Cold, Waves of Russian Missiles Batter Ukraine
articles.snippet: Dozens of missiles knocked out heat and electricity systems around the country including in Kyiv, where two-thirds of its residents had no heat or water.
articles.abstract: Dozens of missiles knocked out heat and electricity systems around the country including in Kyiv, where two-thirds of its residents had no heat or water.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — In subfreezing weather, Russia launched dozens of missiles and drones at Ukrainian energy systems on Friday, pitching millions of civilians into the cold and dark in its deadly campaign to batter — and freeze — the populace into submission.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Marc Santora

articles.headline: In Suspending Journalists on Twitter, Musk Flexes His Media Muscle
articles.snippet: Elon Musk’s moves this week set off a heated debate about complex issues of free speech and online censorship.
articles.abstract: Elon Musk’s moves this week set off a heated debate about complex issues of free speech and online censorship.
articles.lead_paragraph: Elon Musk’s decision to abruptly suspend several journalists from Twitter sparked an outcry on Friday from First Amendment advocates, threats of sanctions from European regulators, and questions about the social media platform’s future as a gathering place for news and ideas.

articles.headline: Restaurateur, Political Donor, Tipster: The Many Roles of FTX’s Ryan Salame
articles.snippet: The co-chief executive of an FTX unit who told regulators about wrongdoing at the exchange was a big Republican donor. He also bought restaurants.
articles.abstract: The co-chief executive of an FTX unit who told regulators about wrongdoing at the exchange was a big Republican donor. He also bought restaurants.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Western Massachusetts, Ryan Salame was known as a local boy turned hometown hero who struck gold as a top executive at FTX, the now-collapsed cryptocurrency exchange, and used some of that wealth to buy a few small restaurants in the area.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein, Kenneth P. Vogel and David Yaffe-Bellany

articles.headline: What Comes Next for the Most Empty Downtown in America
articles.snippet: Tech workers are still at home. The $17 salad place is expanding into the suburbs. So what is left in San Francisco?
articles.abstract: Tech workers are still at home. The $17 salad place is expanding into the suburbs. So what is left in San Francisco?
articles.lead_paragraph: The coffee rush. The lunch rush. The columns of headphone-equipped tech workers rushing in and out of train stations. The lanyard-wearing visitors who crowded the sidewalks when a big conference was in town.
articles.byline: By Conor Dougherty, Emma Goldberg and Aaron Wojack

articles.headline: U.S. Scrutinizes Political Donations by Sam Bankman-Fried and Allies
articles.snippet: Federal prosecutors appear to be focusing on possible wrongdoing by cryptocurrency executives, rather than by Democratic or Republican politicians. But the inquiries widen an explosive campaign finance scandal.
articles.abstract: Federal prosecutors appear to be focusing on possible wrongdoing by cryptocurrency executives, rather than by Democratic or Republican politicians. But the inquiries widen an explosive campaign finance scandal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal prosecutors in Manhattan are seeking information from Democrats and Republicans about donations from the disgraced cryptocurrency entrepreneur Sam Bankman-Fried and two former executives at the companies he co-founded.
articles.byline: By Kenneth P. Vogel and Ken Bensinger

articles.headline: O Come All Ye Faithful, Except When Christmas Falls on a Sunday
articles.snippet: Worried about coaxing people into pews when they’d rather be in their pajamas, some Protestant pastors are canceling Sunday services on Dec. 25.
articles.abstract: Worried about coaxing people into pews when they’d rather be in their pajamas, some Protestant pastors are canceling Sunday services on Dec. 25.
articles.lead_paragraph: StoneBridge Christian Church in eastern Nebraska is known locally for hosting a big annual fireworks event, which this fall included 15 food trucks and portable firepits for making s’mores. But it’s the Christmas season that is “our Super Bowl,” said the church’s executive pastor, Mitch Chitwood. This year, the church’s four locations in the Omaha area will host four “Jingle Jam” family parties in December and nine services on Christmas Eve, complete with classic carols, Christmas-themed coffee drinks and a festive photo booth in the lobby.

articles.headline: Military Spending Surges, Creating New Boom for Arms Makers
articles.snippet: The combination of the war in Ukraine and concern about longer-term threats from Russia and China is driving a bipartisan push to increase U.S. capacity to produce weapons.
articles.abstract: The combination of the war in Ukraine and concern about longer-term threats from Russia and China is driving a bipartisan push to increase U.S. capacity to produce weapons.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The prospect of growing military threats from both China and Russia is driving bipartisan support for a surge in Pentagon spending, setting up another potential boom for weapons makers that is likely to extend beyond the war in Ukraine.

articles.headline: In the U.S., His Site Has Been Linked to Massacres. In Japan, He’s a Star.
articles.snippet: Hiroyuki Nishimura has become a famous voice for disenchanted young Japanese. What he talks much less about is his ownership of the notorious website 4chan.
articles.abstract: Hiroyuki Nishimura has become a famous voice for disenchanted young Japanese. What he talks much less about is his ownership of the notorious website 4chan.
articles.lead_paragraph: He has amassed millions of followers on social media, where he opines on the failures of Japanese society. He has appeared both on the catwalk at one of Japan’s biggest fashion shows and in a government video urging people to watch their finances. In a national poll, high school students said he was their top pick for prime minister.
articles.byline: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno

articles.headline: The Education of CNN’s Chris Licht
articles.snippet: The network’s chief executive knew the job would not be easy. But this hard?
articles.abstract: The network’s chief executive knew the job would not be easy. But this hard?
articles.lead_paragraph: When Chris Licht told his boss, Stephen Colbert, the host of the CBS program “Late Show With Stephen Colbert,” in February that he had been offered the chief executive job at CNN, Mr. Colbert was blunt: “Definitely don’t go do that.”

articles.headline: Proud Boys Trial Is Set to Open, Focusing on Role in Jan. 6 Violence
articles.snippet: The charge of seditious conspiracy is the same as in a recent trial of members of the Oath Keepers militia, but the Proud Boys defendants are accused of a central role in the fighting at the Capitol.
articles.abstract: The charge of seditious conspiracy is the same as in a recent trial of members of the Oath Keepers militia, but the Proud Boys defendants are accused of a central role in the fighting at the Capitol.
articles.lead_paragraph: [The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack will hold its last public meeting. Follow for live updates.]

articles.headline: Streaming’s Golden Age Is Suddenly Dimming
articles.snippet: After years of breakneck growth, the number of scripted TV series orders made by networks and streamers is in decline.
articles.abstract: After years of breakneck growth, the number of scripted TV series orders made by networks and streamers is in decline.
articles.lead_paragraph: American television viewers have become accustomed to it: Dozens of premieres every month, hundreds of shows every year, a guarantee from Hollywood that there’s always going to be something new to watch.

articles.headline: Want to Understand Television’s Troubles? Look at AMC.
articles.snippet: The company has struggled to earn enough from streaming to make up for losses from its traditional cable business. It is a story widespread in the industry.
articles.abstract: The company has struggled to earn enough from streaming to make up for losses from its traditional cable business. It is a story widespread in the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Actors wearing fangs and fake blood roamed the basement of the Roxy Hotel in September in an ornate celebration of a new AMC Networks show, “Interview With the Vampire,” based on the wildly popular 1976 Anne Rice novel. Hopes rode high. Executives at AMC Networks — vaunted home of “Mad Men,” “Breaking Bad” and “The Walking Dead” — thought they had a hit for the streaming era.

articles.headline: In Heart of Peru’s Protest, a Pause to Mourn the Dead
articles.snippet: Confrontations between protesters and the Peruvian authorities have left at least 25 dead and hundreds injured. Nowhere may tensions be higher than in the highland city of Ayacucho.
articles.abstract: Confrontations between protesters and the Peruvian authorities have left at least 25 dead and hundreds injured. Nowhere may tensions be higher than in the highland city of Ayacucho.
articles.lead_paragraph: AYACUCHO, Peru — Beyond the burning tires and roadblocks guarded by angry protesters, after the justice palace had been set on fire and the military had been sent to intervene, a funeral was underway.
articles.byline: By Julie Turkewitz and Victor Moriyama

articles.headline: ‘The Last Straw’: Twitter Users Rage Over Elon Musk’s Latest Actions
articles.snippet: Fury mounted over Mr. Musk’s moves to prevent Twitter users from sharing links to other social media platforms. The billionaire also asked whether he should remain as head of the service.
articles.abstract: Fury mounted over Mr. Musk’s moves to prevent Twitter users from sharing links to other social media platforms. The billionaire also asked whether he should remain as head of the service.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — High-profile Twitter users were suspended without warning or explanation, then abruptly reinstated.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger and Ryan Mac

articles.headline: Tesla’s Direct Sales Model Helps It Thwart Customer Lawsuits
articles.snippet: Sales contracts prevent buyers of the company’s electric cars from pursuing class-action suits if something goes wrong.
articles.abstract: Sales contracts prevent buyers of the company’s electric cars from pursuing class-action suits if something goes wrong.
articles.lead_paragraph: Until last month, a class-action lawsuit by Tesla owners looked as if it would reveal new details about the carmaker’s self-driving technology, which has been blamed for serious accidents and deaths.

articles.headline: How Naming the James Webb Telescope Turned Into a Fight Over Homophobia
articles.snippet: Did the former head of NASA discriminate against gay people? One physicist tried to rebut the accusation, only to find himself the target of attacks.
articles.abstract: Did the former head of NASA discriminate against gay people? One physicist tried to rebut the accusation, only to find himself the target of attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: For half a decade now, influential young scientists have denounced NASA’s decision to name its deep-space telescope after James E. Webb, who led the space agency to the cusp of the 1969 moon landing. This man, they insisted, was a homophobe who oversaw a purge of gay employees.

articles.headline: Trust the Models? In This Economy?
articles.snippet: Years into the pandemic, it is still difficult to get a handle on what comes next for the economy by looking at examples from the past.
articles.abstract: Years into the pandemic, it is still difficult to get a handle on what comes next for the economy by looking at examples from the past.
articles.lead_paragraph: Historical data has always been critical to those who make economic predictions. But three years into the pandemic, America is suffering through an economic whiplash of sorts — and the past is proving anything but a reliable guide.

articles.headline: From Zero Covid to No Plan: Behind China’s Pandemic U-Turn
articles.snippet: After micromanaging the coronavirus strategy for nearly three years, the country’s leader, Xi Jinping, has suddenly left the populace to improvise.
articles.abstract: After micromanaging the coronavirus strategy for nearly three years, the country’s leader, Xi Jinping, has suddenly left the populace to improvise.
articles.lead_paragraph: The southwestern city of Chongqing was the latest frontline of Xi Jinping’s “zero Covid” war, until it came to epitomize China’s potentially devastating about-face that has cracked the Communist Party’s edifice of absolute control.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley, Alexandra Stevenson and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Epic Games to Pay $520 Million Over Children’s Privacy and Trickery Charges
articles.snippet: The creator of Fortnite and other popular games violated children’s privacy and duped millions of users into unwanted purchases, federal regulators said.
articles.abstract: The creator of Fortnite and other popular games violated children’s privacy and duped millions of users into unwanted purchases, federal regulators said.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Epic Games released Fortnite five years ago, the video game quickly became a cultural sensation among millions of teenagers and children. It was easy to sign up and start playing and talking or text chatting with strangers through the game.
